45.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, shooting paintballs at an approaching asteroid could help change its trajectory, Earth's fate might be sealed, and researchers figure out how an ancient civilization moved the Moai statues.

46.title: Energy Use Down, Renewables Up
46.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, American energy use is down overall, while our use of clean energy is up, exercise is found to be a natural mood booster, and hermit crabs are more ruthless than we thought.

47.title: Dark Spot on the Moon
47.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists find the cause of the Moon's dark spot, drones may soon be flying around with commercial planes, and researchers work on breaking your bad habits.

48.title: Super Sense of Smell
48.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, animals use their sense of smell like humans use their vision, agriculture is a critical player in global climate change, and Google releases a new and improved voice search.

49.title: Asteroid Belt Could Be Beneficial for the Building Blocks of Life
49.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, an elephant speaks Korean, scientists put together a comprehensive bird family tree, and new research says that the presence of an asteroid belt determines whether complex life evolves on an Earth-like planet.

50.title: Analyzing Mars' Atmosphere
50.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Curiosity analyzes the Mars atmosphere, the International Space Station turns twelve, and a lack of sleep costs more than you might think.

51.title: The Great Extinction
51.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, it took a long time for species to recover from the Great Extinction, the search for UFOs may be coming to a close, and new radar technology could better predict volcanic eruptions.

52.title: Whisking for the Blind
52.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists study a rats' whisker use to help the blind better navigate, star formation slows, and middle age heart health could predict a longer life.

53.title: Move It to Lose It
53.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists have quantified how many years exercise can add to your lifespan, JPL's Curiosity team resets the clock, and sharks need a new public image.

54.title: Coffee Could Go the Way of the Dinosaurs
54.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Canada names a new dinosaur, coffee could become extinct by 2080, and swishing sugar helps control cravings.

55.title: Toxic Seaweed Cleared from Coral by Fish Soldier
55.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, mutualistic fish protect coral, scientists say listen to your gut, and meth could possibly be used to treat the flu.

56.title: Even Space Satellites Are Effected by Climate Change
56.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, increased CO2 in atmosphere drawing satellites closer to Earth, new perfume candy leaves you smelling like a rose, and first solar eclipse over Australia in decades.

57.title: Leonids to Put on Quite a Show this Weekend
57.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Leonid meteor shower is the best show in town, researchers find meditation has long-lasting effect, and a new Google report says that government surveillance is on the rise.

58.title: Marriage Can Give You a Longer Life
58.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers successfully map the first domestic pig's genome, new research says marriage increase lifespan, and researchers are providing hope for patients in vegetative states.

59.title: Is There a Symphony in Your Head?
59.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new research shows animals in captivity exhibit boredom, scientists say the fear of relaxation is a real phobia, and Chinese researchers have transformed EEG waves into musical compositions.

60.title: To the Moon! The Water Rush Is On!
60.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, commercial companies are scrambling to find water on the moon, research shows that kids who learn to swim earlier are smarter, and the Brasilia Zoo in Brazil plans to start cloning endangered species.

61.title: Even Apes Get the Middle-aged Blues
61.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new research shows that apes suffer from a mid-life crisis, a study suggests that happier kids end up being wealthier adults later in life, and "gamers" are more adept at using robot surgical equipment than medical residents.

62.title: Curiosity to Spend Thanksgiving on Mars Carving Rocks Instead of Turkey
62.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Curiosity will be collecting more samples on Mars by hammering rocks, a new bill could provide law enforcement more freedom to observe your email and online accounts, and researchers are developing an electronic nose to aid in sniffing out explosives.

63.title: Dogs Learn to Associate Objects Through Size and Textures
63.plot: n this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new study shows that dogs associate words different from humans, researchers are streaming Braille patterns directly to the eyes of the blind allowing them to read, and ultrasound images show that fetuses yawn too.

64.title: Pac-man Seen on Saturn Moon
64.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new images of Saturn's moon Tethys looks like Pac-man, a new study says that the best way to look at a person's face is below their eyes, and throwing negative thoughts away actually helps people forget them.

65.title: Would You Move to Mars?
65.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, SpaceX announces plans to colonize Mars by the 2030s, a report reveals that the U.S. had planned to blow up the moon during the Cold War, and GM announces two of its new cars will come equipped with SIRI.

66.title: Are You Addicted to Your Cell Phone?
66.plot: One researcher's claims that Yeti DNA related to homo sapiens, cigarette smoking is found to significantly slow cognitive functioning, and researchers say cell phone addiction is a real disorder.

67.title: Ice Found on Mercury's Polar Crater Rims
67.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, study shows that online piracy actually benefits blockbuster films, a new study shows American students are poor at math, and new births on the decline.

68.title: Body Language Is the Best Way to Read Emotions
68.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers discover body language more accurate cue to emotions than facial expressions, sleep is more effective at easing pain that painkillers, and growth bands provide basis for determining lobsters' ages.

69.title: Japanese Astronaut to Bring Robot with Him in 2013
69.plot: A humanoid robot will accompany an astronaut to the ISS in 2013, we celebrate the 20th anniversary of the text message, and researchers discover that the "Pinnochio" effect really exists.

70.title: Moderate Coffee Consumption Can Help Stave Off Type 2 Diabetes
70.plot: n this episode of the Daily Orbit, new study shows coffee can help reduce risks for Type 2 Diabetes, a new app in development will have smartphones determining users' moods, and military tactics are being influenced by squirrels "deceptive" behaviors.

71.title: NASA Has Plans for Future Mars Missions
71.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA announces a new Mars rover set for 2020, new data reveals moon's crust "pulverized", and red wine reduces risks for bowel cancer by 50%.

72.title: Golden Spike Wants You to Fly to the Moon and Back
72.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new company plans commercial trips to the moon and back by 2020, Verizon patents a new TV box that would allow for targeted advertising by observing the spectator, and a new study shows that dogs are 70% accurate in sniffing out lung cancer.

73.title: Hunt Is on the Rid the Everglades of Invasive Pythons
73.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Florida announces a competition to help rid the everglades of non-native pythons, new study shows beer heps to fight respiratory viruses, and scientists say large trees are rapidly dying out.

74.title: Playing Violent Video Games Leads to Violence
74.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new study suggests that playing violent video games does lead to more aggressive behavior, new genetically engineered algae can produce cancer treating drug at a lower cost, and porcupine quills are inspiring a new medical adhesive

75.title: Get Ready for a Spectacular Media Show
75.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, we prepare for the Geminid meteor shower, researchers have created a test to see if we are living in a computer simulation, and a study shows that establishments in Manhattan are mislabeling fish.

76.title: Saturn Moon Titan Has Something in Common with Egypt
76.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new images of Saturn's moon Titan show a mini-Nile River on its surface, archaeologists begin drilling through 2 miles of ice in Anarctica in search of life, and we celebrate 50 years of space exploration!

77.title: NASA's Twin Moon Probes to Crash Into the Moon Next Week
77.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA's GRAIL moon probes reach the end of their mission and will crash into the moon, a new study finds that cheese has been around for 7,000 years, and researchers advise writers suffering from writer's block to take a nature hike to get inspired.

78.title: Doctors Urge Space Physicals for Cosmic Travelers
78.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, doctors prepare for pre and post space travel physicals with the likelihood of commercial space travel, a University of Colorado-Boulder professor creates ping-pong sized robots he calls "droplets", and researchers say that a substantial number of automobile accidents occur from wandering minds.

79.title: Moon Crash Successful for Twin GRAIL Probes
79.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, GRAIL twin probes successfully crash into their lunar resting place, IBM predicts that in 5 years computers will also have the 5 human senses, and researchers say ice cream could be used to make fuel.

80.title: The Science Behind Rudolph's Shiny Red Nose
80.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists explain why Rudolph's nose is so glowing red, CERN is giving is Large Hadron Collider a much needed break for maintenance, and new sensors give real-time air quality and air pollution data via smartphones and computers.

81.title: Cloned Humans in 50 Years: Why Not?
81.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Sir John Gurdon says human cloning will be possible in 50 years, astronomers discover a possibly habitable planet in the sun star system Tau Ceti, and NORAD ditches Google for Bing for their 2012 Santa Tracker.

82.title: Human Intelligence Is Not All About IQ
82.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new study says that IQ is not an effective measurement of intelligence, a new report says insect protein may be a more sustainable alternative to meat and dairy, and real people experience Scrooge-like turnarounds.

83.title: Asteroid 2011 AG5 Will Not Hit Earth in 2040
83.plot: New data reveals that Earth is safe from a once possible asteroid impact in 2040, "Franken-fish" gets a stamp of approval from the FDA, and the Brontosaurus never really existed.

84.title: Robot Boy Is More Appealing Than Traditional Robots
84.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the new Roboy is a "soft robot" that will be built to be more appealing to humans for interaction, Comet Ison will light up the night sky in 2013, and archaeologists unearth a cone-shaped skull dating back 1,000 years.

85.title: Mars Rover Has a Big Year Planned in 2013
85.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the charity Sense about Science released its annual Top Celebrity Science Abusers in 2012 report, new study shows that neuroticism might actually be good for your health, and pandas could hold the key to a new way of combating antibiotic resistant microbes.

86.title: Ring in the New Year with the Quadrantid Meteor Shower
86.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Quadrantids meteor shower is in town, new study shows that recess is vital to kids performance in school, and research shows that cosmic radiation from deep space exploration could put astronauts at an increased risk for Alzheimer's.

87.title: Can Being in Space Actually Make You Grow Taller?
87.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists try to understand why astronauts grow taller in space and shrink back to normal on Earth, new research finds that baby actually start to differentiate languages in the womb, and smoking actually increases anxiety.

88.title: NASA Working to Turn Trash Into Radiation Shiels
88.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA plans to transform trash in space into shields to protect astronauts from cosmic radiation during deep space travel, a new study shows that the color of food and drink packaging can affect the taste, and astronomers at Caltech estimate that there are at least a 100 billion planets in our Milky Way galaxy.

89.title: Consumer Electronics Show Has Alot to Offer This Year
89.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, we look at the latest technology featured at this year's CES in Las Vegas, conservationist say Alaska's Cook Inlet Beluga whales are still in decline, and a new study says that how you see yourself in 10 years could be inaccurate.

90.title: What Would a Living Mars Really Look Like?
90.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, software engineer Kevin Gill creates his simulation of "A Living Mars," a research team in Russian creates there on simulation of a deep space mission to Mars to see the sleeping affects on astronauts, and jumbo squid flourish in record numbers on the Southern California coast.

91.title: Asteroid Will Be Making a Close Appearance Tonight
91.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Asteroid Apophis passes very close to Earth today, the Kepler mission has 461 new candidates for planet classification, and 2012 was the hottest year on record for the U.S.

92.title: CES Day 2 Had Plenty of Winners and Losers
92.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, we look at some of the cool technology on display at CES in Vegas, the Cassini mission says it may have discovered ice on Saturn's moon Titan, and artificially sweetened drinks may lead to depression.

93.title: Waste Not Want Not: Report Outlines Growing Food Waste
93.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, we do the CES wrap-up, a new report says that 2 billion tons of food is wasted every year, and are brown eyes more trustworthy than blue eyes?

94.title: Climate Change Effects Already Being Seen
94.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, astronomers say we are all clear of an asteroid Apophis-Earth collision in 2036, seismologists discover that Northern and Southern Californias could experience an earthquake at the same time one day, and another study shows that marriage is good for longevity.

95.title: Spaceport America Liability Waivers an Issue for Virgin Galactic
95.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Virgin Galactic threatens to move shop from Spaceport America if they do not agree to extend liability waivers to manufacturers and suppliers, new research says Facebook can make overweight and in-debt, and eating strawberries and blueberries could lower a woman's cardiovascular disease risk by one-third.

96.title: Russia Has New Moon and Rocket Plans
96.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Russia announces a 2015 moon mission in search of lunar water and a new rocket for 2020, robot jobs are outpacing humans, and new research says that happiness is in the "wanting" and not the "having."

97.title: What's the Status of Your Memory?
97.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Iran Space Organization prepares to send a monkey into space, NASA is building on to the ISS, and new research says people remember Facebook status's better than passages from books or even pictures of others.

98.title: Mona Lisa's Famous Smile Beamed from the Moon to NASA
98.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA beamed an image of the Mona Lisa to the moon using laser communication,researchers discover that crustaceans actually do feel pain, and MIT researchers identify volunteers in genetics research from their DNA with just a laptop and an Internet connection.

99.title: Surrogate Needed to Carry Neanderthal Clone Baby
99.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, one geneticist says he is very close to cloning a Neanderthal and needs to find a surrogate to carry it, Google execs propose an alternative to the online password, and a new study says that Mom's who lead the household have a reduced professional drive.

100.title: Cosmic Blast from the Past
100.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, carbonate rings in cedar trees dating back to 774 to 775 AD tell a story of a cosmic blast in the 8th century, new research says that both Chinese and American parents lie to their children to get them to behave, and the auroras may be used to find other planets and planetary bodies outside of our solar system.

101.title: Asteroid Mining Adventure Announced by Deep Space Industries
101.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Deep Space Industries plans to send spacecraft to mine for metals on nearby asteroids in 2015, new "privacy visors" will confuse facial recognition technology, and new research says that public acceptance of climate change may have been influenced by the rate at which certain words made their way from technical jargon to mainstream vernacular.

102.title: The Sun Can Be in More Colors Than Just Yelloq
102.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA shows the many colors of the suns different wavelenghs, NIH plans to retire 400 research chimpanzees, and man's best friend may have evolved from wolves scavenging the waste baskets of our ancestors.

103.title: Dinosaur Fossils Call Into Question the Evolution of Flight
103.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new study shows the benefit of medical marijuana for elderly nursing home patrons, a recently discovered fossil may precede the previously thought ancestors of the modern bird, and new research shows a correlation between lightning and headaches.

104.title: Remembering the Apollo 1 Astronauts
104.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, we remember the tragic event of the Apollo 1 mission that costs 3 astronauts their lives, scientists say that global warming is curable and possibly not as bad as we thought, and "waste heat' generated by cities can cause warming or cooing a far away as a 1,000 miles.

105.title: Big Foot News Screaming Onto the Scene Once More
105.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, supposed audio of a Sasquatch in the U.S.'s Northern Pacific is causing a stir, Iran successfully launches a monkey into space, and PepsiCo announces it is replacing a product in Gatorade that's also in flame retardant.

106.title: DARPA Wants to Create Self-destructing Hardware
106.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, DARPA invites scientists to help in creating Vanishing Programmable Resources that will self-destruct on command, new study shows that vegetables cause more hospitalizations than poultry, and stray and feral cats are causing more bird and mammal elimination that habit loss, agriculture chemicals, or hunting.

107.title: Mass of Planetary Nursery TW Hydrae Large Enough for Many Planets
107.plot: On this episode of the Daily Oribt, astronomers discover that the TW Hydrae system has enough mass for 52 Jupiter size planets, scientists have created a new model to determine if a planet could support life, and a new study says vegetarians are 32% less likely to be hospitalized or die of heart disease.

108.title: Online Interaction or In-Person: Either Way Works for Generation X
108.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new study shows that Gen-Xers are as likely to engage in online interactions as traditional face-to-face, one scientists says he can explain why homing pigeons often lose their way home, and we remember the Columbia Spacecraft tragedy of 2003.

109.title: 3D on the Moon!
109.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, ESA is looking to 3D printer technology to build a lunar base, another UK man scores big with a whale vomit find, and study shows that billboards advertising food can increase an area's per capita obesity percentage.

110.title: Google Glass Project Adds Another Component
110.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Google looks to vibrating glasses to transmit sound instead of ear buds, the Bristish Army employs the use of mini drones to conduct battlefield surveillance, and fear in the brain is not solely managed by the amygdala.

111.title: Felix Baumgartner Fell Faster According to Official Reports
111.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, official results show that Felix Baumgartner actually reached speeds of 10 mph faster than estimated results during his space jump, the new Halley VI station replaces the Halley V station for researchers in Antartica, and new research says Americans could help the environment by adopting a European work model.

112.title: When Did the Caveman Really Die? New Dating Methods Upends Common Theories
112.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new dating method suggests that the Neanderthal became extinct earlier than previously thought, 3D printing technology is now being used to create stem cells, and a new study shows that cocktails made with diet sodas leave the drinker more intoxicated than those mixed with regular sugary soft drinks.

113.title: Thanksgiving Comet ISON to Become a Movie Star
113.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, comet ISON will light up the November sky and my even outshine the full moon, many Americans say that they are "quitting" Facebook, and a smaller wallet means a larger waistline according to a new study.

114.title: Curiosity Rover Really Digs Mars
114.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Curiosity rover digs a hole in rock "John Klein" to search for evidence of past water, ECOCEAN is calling all amateur photographer to send their pictures of the whale shark, and AVG says kids as young as 11 are writing malicious codes.

115.title: Dogs Are Smarter Than You Think
115.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new study shows that dogs are more likely to steal food in the dark or when humans aren't looking, rumors surface of a possible Apple smartwatch, and a new laser device developed to determine isotopes on Mars may be used to determine counterfeit foods on Mars.

116.title: Don't Go in the Water! Shark Bites Are on the Rise!
116.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, 2012 saw the most shark bites since 2000, carbon released from melting permafrost in the Arctic is contributing to global warming, and scientists say that they can "shut off" cold sensing neurons of the body.

117.title: Black Hole Growth Is Not Limited to Only Galaxy Collisions
117.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, black holes are growing faster than astronomers previously thought, learning an instrument early in childhood helps form brain connections, and mindfulness meditation helps your brain learn to control pain and depression.

118.title: Asteroid Weaves Its Way Past Earth and We Didn't Die!
118.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, asteroid 2012 DA14 comes a mere 17,000 miles from Earth, a meteorite strike Russia injuring 1,000 people, and a new study says billboards cause distracted driving.

119.title: Australia Is Home to the Third Largest Impact Crater
119.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers say a 12 mile wide crater impact in Australia is the biggest in the world, a new system is letting the iPad drive a car, and back trouble may have been an evolutionary problem.

120.title: Mercury Gets the 3D Color Treatment
120.plot: Mercury gets a whole new image with new pictures taken by the Messenger probe, scientists find traces of water in a lunar sample, and researchers say too much TV is making kids mean.

121.title: Will Our Universe Ever Come to an End?
121.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists say an alternative universe could one day destroy our universe, engineers are programming a robot with the ability to learn, and acupuncture may be a cure for allergies.

122.title: Kepler Scientists Say They Have Found the Smallest Planet Ever
122.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists say that a newly discovered planet in the Kepler 37 system is the smallest yet, telomeres on chromosomes may predict susceptibility to the common cold, and a new map shows meteoric activity since 2300 BCE.

123.title: Buy Your Ticket to Mars in 2018
123.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, an independent company is planning to send tourists on a 500 day trip to Mars in January 2018, giant goldfish are infesting Lake Tahoe and disrupting the ecosystem, and researchers find the deepest hydrothermal vent in the world in the Cayman Trough by accident.

124.title: Snowfall Could Diminish Due to Increasing CO2 Levels
124.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the US will see a decrease in snowfall over the next 100 years due to global warming while the polar caps will see more, researchers say that the protein FOXP2 explains why women are more loquacious, and this year's flu vaccine is failing in fighting off the flu.

125.title: Dying White Dward Stars Could Support Habitable Exoplanets
125.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, astronomers say that dying dwarf stars could support life on habitable exoplanets, a new study shows that chimps like to do puzzles for fun too, and a new initiative campaigns against war robotic technology.

126.title: Celebrate Polar Bear Day and Reduce Your Carbon Footprint
126.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, we celebrate polar bears and try to help them out by reducing our carbon footprint, sleep deprivation leads to a major drop in gene activity, and scientists say that "space dust" is enough to knock out a satellites communication.

127.title: Giving Birth to a Planet
127.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists say they may have found a forming planet in the disc around the young star HD 100546, a new robot P37 S65 cares for the elderly, and scientists examine the phenomenon of pleasure from pain.

128.title: Aquarius Satellite Shows Ocean Salinity Levels Are on the Rise
128.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA's Aquarius satellite reveals rising ocean salinity levels, China announced a manned mission to space, and a new urine-test app called UCheck is soon to be released.

129.title: Another Rendezvous for the Dragon and the Space Station
129.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a resupply mission to the ISS gets a little hairy for the SpaceX Dragon Capsule, DARPA's "Big Dog" robot learns to throw, and Cancer Research UK is looking for a game for a cure to get gamers involved in cancer research.

130.title: Cassini Snaps Venus Peering Through Saturn's Rings
130.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Cassini spacecraft captures some unique images of Venus from Saturn's perspective, Thailand pledges to ban the ivory trade, and global warming may open up new trade routes through the Arctic and North Pole.

131.title: Curiosity Rover Back on Track, for Now
131.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, JPL has to switch Curiosity over to a redundant computer after its main suffers from a memory issue, researchers say they have solved the mystery of what caused the 1937 Hindenberg Airship explosion, and a new fossils place ancient giant camels in Canada's High Arctic.

132.title: Comets May Have Seeded Life on Earth
132.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists say meteorites could have brought the building blocks of life to Earth, researchers are using MRI technology to read people's minds, and new research says that sex may be better than meds for a headache.

133.title: Clues to Mars Watery Past Found Just Below the Surface
133.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new map of the Martian subsurface shows buried channels which suggests evidence of past flooding, researchers say a diet including alot of processed meats can lead to more disease and death, and salt may be the culprit behind the rise in autoimmune diseases.

134.title: 3D Printing Contest to Create Rockets
134.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, DIYROCKETS partners with Sunglasses to announce a 3D rocket printing competition, scientists have found that dolphins give each other names, and a toxin found in bee venom may be effective against HIV.

135.title: New Star System Found in Our Own Backyard
135.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new solar system named after the WISE satellite has been found just 6.5 light years away from our own, programmers create an Internet just for robots called RoboCloud, and what do your Facebook "likes" reveal about you.

136.title: Sign of Life on Mars? Curiosity Team Says Yes!
136.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Curiosity finds evidenced of the chemical ingredients of life in rock powder, one scientists claims to have found algae on a meteorite sample, and helmets don't protect from concussions says doctors.

137.title: Burnout at Work Can Burnout Your Heart
137.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers say burnout at work is a better predictor of coronary heart disease than physical activity or smoking, astronomers recently found that starbursts happened much earlier than thought in our universe's history, and we celebrate Pi Day!

138.title: God Particle Confirmed by CERN
138.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, CERN confirms that it did indeed find a Higgs boson particle last summer, a new chimpanzee robot called CHIMP enters DARPA's robot challenge, and one YouTube user is making waves with his watery illusion video.

139.title: iPhone App for Your Quadcopter Drone Released by ESA
139.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, ESA releases an iPhone App for your quadcopter in order to crowdsource research efforts for drones, the new "Lazarus Project" is attempting to revive an extinct frog, and new Mobile LIDAR will soon change the way we map our world.

140.title: The Red Planet May Have Once Been Blue
140.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new clay-containing rock samples taken by Curiosity suggests that Mars once had a very watery past, researchers find microbes living in the depths of the Mariana Trench, and an MIT project is seeking to revolutionize robot production by creating 3D printable robot technology.

141.title: Mars Rover Back Up and Running After Temporary Glitch
141.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, another computer glitch puts Curiosity into safe mode, Samsung announces its plans for a smartwatch, and a 100,000 year old skull suggests that our ancestors were prone to inbreeding.

142.title: Asteroid Detection Plan Needed
142.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA meets with Congress to brainstorm about asteroid defense, the U.S. military says its seeking to find a more secure wireless network, and scientists successfully sequence the Neanderthal genome from a toe fragment.

143.title: The Best of the Daily Orbit
143.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, we take a look back at some of the more fun and wacky moments from the Daily Orbit.

144.title: Blazing Fireball Seen Along the East Coast This Weekend
144.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a meteorite blazes across the East Coast sky so bright it's classified as a fireball, researchers say it was a comet and not an asteroid that actually led to the extinction of the dinosaurs, and MIT says sapphire screens may save your phone from cracking in the near future.

145.title: Venus Storm Is Constantly on the Move
145.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists find that the center of Venus giant storm wanders around the poles differently at different altitudes, the Texas longhorn is found to be a "pure" descendant of ancestral cattle from the Iberian Peninsula, and babies who begin eating solid foods too early may be at a higher risk of obesity and lifetime weight gain.

146.title: Mini-Supernova Gets a New Classification
146.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists find a previously undiscovered form of supernova, SpaceX's Dragron capsule completes another successful resupply despite technical problems early on, and a new report says that more and more Americans are moving to the coast.

147.title: Saturn's Moons and Rings Are Like an Antique Shop
147.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists say the colder spring is a product of melting sea ice, new Cassini images reveal that Saturn's rings and moons evolved at the beginning of the solar system, and new smartphone assistant in development will be able to relay emotions via messaging.

148.title: Galaxy Shines in New Huddle Hidden Treasure Image
148.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, an amateur astronomer uncovers a beautiful photo of the spiral galaxy Messier 77 in Hubble "Hidden Treasures" competition, new DNA sequencing provides hope in the prevention of breast and ovarian cancer, and engineers are building a new robotic jellyfish named Cyro that for surveillance purposes and monitoring the environment.

149.title: Microchips Might One Day Help Fight the Urge to Eat
149.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers say they have developed a tiny microchip that helps control the appetite,the FBI releases memo saying that Guy Hottel memo of 1950 is the most read document in their now public "Vault", and Americans are moving to the coast in ever increasing numbers.

150.title: What Do You Do When Your Panda Isn't Feeling the Love?
150.plot: Handlers at the National Zoo performed artificial insemination on a female panda when natural breeding attempts were unsuccessful, the Arctic is getting greener, and a California sea lion keeps the beat.

151.title: Black Hole Wakes Up and Snacks on a Super-Jupiter
151.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a black hole that had been dormant for decades feeds on a sub-stellar object, DARPA is training a new robot to change tires, and the Wright brothers may not have been the first in flight after all.

152.title: The Hunt for Exoplanets Is On!
152.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, astronomers say they have a new method that could lead to the discovery 100 billion Earth-like planets, trace metals in the soil may be to blame for the bumble bee die out, and new research shows that chimpanzees--like humans-have the ability to recognize their own cognitive states.

153.title: 3D Printing of Synthetic Tissues
153.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, 3D printers create synthetic materials to replace damaged tissues in the human body, global warming may be leading to an increase number of Adelie penguins, and tarantula the size of a human's face is discovered in Sri Lanka.

154.title: Is Asteroid Capture NASA's Next Big Thing?
154.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA plans to bring an asteroid closer to Earth for astronauts to travel to and explore, NASA also celebrates the 40th anniversary of its Pioneer 11 spacecraft, and scientists say they can read people's dreams by monitoring brain behavior.

155.title: Curiosity Finds Evidence of Atmospheric Thinning on Mars
155.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists say that Mars atmosphere has thinned significantly over time, Liquid Robotics breaks a record with its new Wave Glider SV3, and researchers say turbulence on flights will double by 2050.

156.title: Mars Trip? Get There Faster with Nuclear Fusion!
156.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists are developing a nuclear fusion powered rocket engine that could mean a faster trip to Mars, researchers found that your brain automatically assumes you are being stared at, and laziness may be in the genes according to a new study.

157.title: Monitoring Ice Flows in Antarctica
157.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers say the best way to monitor Antarctica's health is by ice flow, newly uncovered dinosaur eggs fossils have pushed the fossil record back for dinosaur embryos a 100 million years, and scientists recreate the sound of the "Big Bang."

158.title: Soviet Era Lander Remains Spotted on Mars
158.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Russian citizen scientists identify possible remains of the Mar 3 Lander in images taken by the Mars Reconnaisance Orbiter, researchers say music affects different brains in the same way, and a new study says that sound stimulation during sleep can enhance memory.

159.title: Titan's Ice Cloud Heralds Changing Seasons
159.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Cassini images show changes in Titan's ice cloud signaling the transition from winter to spring, carbon dating has successfully synced the Anicient Maya and European calendars, and an Iranian man says he has invented a time machine.

160.title: Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo Passes Key Flight Test
160.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Virgin's SpaceShipTwo completed its "Cold Flow" test over the Mojave Desert, Microsoft joins the smartwatch race, and patent war is staged over the patenting of DNA.

161.title: Astronomers Get Ready to Study Saturn's Auroras
161.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, an astronomy A-team begins a month long study of Saturn's northern lights, a new study finds that just the taste of beer alone triggers dopamine release in the brain, and scientists discover that the nicknamed "hobbit" hominid that lived 12,000 years ago actually had a bigger brain than previously thought.

162.title: Proba-3 Satellites to Perform Cosmic Ballet
162.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, ESA's new Proba 3 satellites aim to be the first to demonstrate synchronized flight, aerobic exercise lessens the negative effects of heavy drinking on the brain, and a new study shows that some stress is actually good for you.

163.title: Lyra Constellation Hosts Potential "Super-Earth"
163.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new discovered Kepler planet found in the habitable zone, a new sensor will give robots "feeling," and research shows that sterilized dogs live longer.

164.title: Seismic Activity Measured from Superstorm Sandy
164.plot: Scientists detected seismic waves caused by Superstorm Sandy, the Hubble Telescope celebrates 23 years of space discoveries, and we celebrate Earth Day.

165.title: Microgravity Affects the Immune System
165.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists find that space travel involves an elevated risk of infection and neurological degeneration, human stem cells injected into mice improve enhance their learning and memory, and ants change careers throughout their lifetime.

166.title: Water in Jupiter's Atmosphere Came from Comet
166.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, ESA finds that water on Jupiter arrived via the Shoemaker Levy 9 comet impact in 1994, SpaceX celebrates a fifth successful launch of its Grasshopper reusable rocket, and a group celebrates Earth day by trying to preserve the Redwood trees an interesting way.

167.title: Pink Moon Eclipse Put on Quite a Show
167.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Eastern Hemisphere experiences the first lunar eclipse of 2013 during Spring's Pink Full Moon, engineers say their new LED street light will be the solution to light pollution, and the latest in robotics is "Flipperbot" which can traverse through sand.

168.title: Saturn to Shine This Weekend
168.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Saturn ventures it's closest to the Earth for the year, new images from Cassini explain the water on Saturn phenomenon, and scientists say dark lightning and visible lightning occur together.

169.title: Whales Pass on New Hunting Techniques
169.plot: Researchers learn that cultural transmission explains the spread of new hunting techniques among humpback whales, scientists have genetically modified a herd of sheep to glow in the dark, and a new depth camera projector-based system allows touch-based interfaces to be created anywhere with the swipe of a hand.

170.title: Successful Test Flight for Virgin Galactic
170.plot: Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo reach Mach 1.2 speeds in its first powered test flight, a hurricane-like storm the size of two Earths hovers over Saturn's new pole, and shapeshifiting is the latest in smartphone technology.

171.title: Citizen Scientists Now Help Track Light Pollution
171.plot: A new app called "Loss of the Night" lets citizen scientists evaluate light pollution around the globe, researchers confirm that green sea turtles in Florida are using designated "protected" areas, and students at Carnegie Melon develop a keyboard for a possible smartwatch.

172.title: FERMI Moved to Avoid Defunct Satellite
172.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA has to maneuver its FERMI satellite to avoid Russian space junk, IBM releases its mini-movie made with a cast of atoms, and playing outside helps prevent the development of nearsightedness in children.

173.title: Student Names Asteroid for OSIRIS-REx
173.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a 9 year old student wins NASA's asteroid naming contest, scientists are looking to Martian meteorites found in Antarctica to find clues to if the Red Planet could have once sustained life, and engineers are creating new robot arms inspired by the tail of a seahorse.

174.title: Seasonal Changes Seen on Saturn
174.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Cassini images provides insight into how the planet's magnetosphere changes with the seasons, one scientist says he has found meteorites that provide clues to what caused the Tunguska Event of 1908, and crowdsourcing raises money for a science learning center and museum in honor of Nikola Tesla.

175.title: Electrocardiogram of Neil Armstrong's Heartbeat for Sale
175.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Neil Armstrong's EKG taken during his first step on the moon is up for grabs on the auction block, Curiosity data shows that Mount Sharp was formed from wind and dust instead of water, and one researcher says the hanging gardens of Babylon weren't in Babylon at all.

176.title: NASA to Pursue Manned Mars Mission
176.plot: NASA announces plans to conduct a manned Mission to Mars, a new rocket fuel looks to be more environmentally friendly, and it's the year of the cicadas.

177.title: Spaceport America Gets a New Tenant
177.plot: SpaceX signs a lease at New Mexio's Spaceport America, MarsOne is already taking applications for its future Mars Colony, and an unlikely robot tells you when your breath stinks.

178.title: Where Did Water on the Moon Come From?
178.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, astronomers say the moon maintained water from Earth following the large impact the resulted in the formation of the moon, the Hubble Telescope finds evidence of the building blocks of Earth-like planets around dead stars, and researchers find evidence of a possible lost continent off the coast of Brazil.

179.title: NASA Honors Skylab's 40th Anniversary
179.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA celebrates the 40th anniversary of the space laboratory that paved the way for the International Space Station, the US Naval Research Lab breaks it own endurance record for an unmanned vehicle powered by hydrogen fuel, and chronic back pain is linked to bacteria that can be treated with antibiotics.

180.title: Astronaut Rockstar Belts Out a Bowie Tune
180.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield becomes a singing sensation with his version of David Bowie's "Space Oddity", Rolls-Royce partners with The Bloodhound Project to break the 1000 mph land speed record, and one scientist says that his "test-tube" burger is a possible solution for the impending world hunger crisis.

181.title: Safe Landing for the ISS Expedition 35 Crew
181.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Expedition 35 crew successfully land in Kazhakstan, music lifts our mood and helps up cope, and painted on solar panels may power the future.

182.title: Asteroid Impacts Common on Mars
182.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new estimates put impacts on Mars at more than 200 per year, Google Co-founder Larry Page reveals a medical condition that has limited his public engagements on his Google+ Page, and a new movement seeks to bring down the allowable blood alcohol concentration level for drivers.

183.title: What Is the Color of Music?
183.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, doctors have developed a heart monitor that is thinner than a dollar bill and non-invasive, researchers find that our brains are wired to make music-color connections based on emotions, and Google and NASA partner up to form a quantum computing artificial intelligence lab.

184.title: Caffeine Toothbrush May Give Your Morning a Jump Start
184.plot: Colgate-Palmolive files a patent for a new caffeine-secreting toothbrush, non-native tawny crazy ants take over the Gulf Coast, and the rover Opportunity breaks a record.

185.title: Space Travel Is Hard on Humans and Animals Alike
185.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a Russian capsule returns to Earth carrying a lot fewer animals than when it began it's journey into space, researchers are looking to echolocation for helping the blind and visually impaired, and scientists are training honeybees to detect explosives.

186.title: New Solar Research Is Heating Up
186.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA's new IRIS mission will seek to find out why the Sun's corona gets so hot, NASA jumps on the 3D printing bandwagon with plans for printable space food, and tawny crazy ants take over the Gulf Coast of the U.S.

187.title: Devastating Oklahoma Storms Captured by Satellite
187.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a NASA and NOAA operated satellite system provides data on the storms that ravaged Oklahoma this week, the approach of summer brings wild weather to Titan's northern hemisphere, and telescopes have captured images of two galaxies merging into one.

188.title: Stunning Image Released for VLT's Anniversary
188.plot: On this episode of the Daiy Orbit, NASA celebrates the 15th anniversary of its Very Large Telescope with a beautiful image of a nebula, researchers say they have developed a new way of measuring IQ that removes cultural limitations, and compounds in cinnamon could potentially combat Alzheimer's.

189.title: Apollo 11 Moon Dust Turns Up After 40 Years
189.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, missing moon dust from the Appollo 11 mission has finally been found in a Berkeley lab, scientists say a specific molecule is the reason why we itch, and amphibian numbers are dropping more rapidly than we thought.

190.title: Astronauts Make 6 Hour Journey to the Space Station
190.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, three new crew members for Expedition 36 reach the space station after a six hour journey, an ancient bryophyte plan is found alive and growing after being buried beneath a glacier for hundreds of years, and Microsoft says social networking is actually productive for employees.

191.title: New Hope for Resurrecting the Mammoth
191.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers find a mammoth carcass with still flowing blood upping the chances of "de-extincting" the woolly mammoth, Moon Express plans to deliver the first private telescope to the moon by 2015, and Planetary Resources kicks of its Kickstarter campaign to crow-fund a space telescope.

192.title: Curiosity Finds More Evidence of Past Water on Mars
192.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Curiosity finds smooth pebbles on the Martian surface that suggests once flowing water, researchers turn off mosquitoes sense of smell, and new evidence on when turtles developed their shells.

193.title: What Slimy Creature Is Pretty in Pink?
193.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new hot pink slug is discovered atop Australia's Mount Kaputar, researchers analyze Neil Armstrong's legendary moon quote, and do new sonar images show the wing of Amelia Earhart's Lockheed Electra aircraft?

194.title: Solar Power Is Powering On
194.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, ESO's Very Large Telescope captures an image of a new exo-planet orbiting its host star, the Solar Impulse completes the third leg of its transcontinental journey, and researchers successfully regenerate functioning liver cells in a lab setting.

195.title: Triceratops Trio Found in Wyoming
195.plot: On this episode of the Daily Obit, scientists hypothesize that solar winds electrify exo-planets in other solar systems, a rancher finds the remains of three triceratops in Wyoming, and captcha codes prove difficult for the blind and visually impaired.

196.title: Astronomers Find Comet Factory
196.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists name an extinct lizard for the late rocker Jim Morrison, a new study verifies that sunscreen does indeed prevent wrinkles, and astronomers using ALMA find a veritable comet factory.

197.title: New Robot Helps Fight Fires
197.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new robot helps to fight fires by creating 3D imaging of burning structures, the TW Hydrae system provides insight into the characteristics of our Sun in its youth, and the National Security Agency receives a court order demanding Verizon to turn over customers' phone records.

198.title: Mars Rover Finds Evidence of Water That You Could Drink
198.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Opportunity finds a clay rich rock that indicates non-acidic water in Mars' past, gray wolves could soon be released from federal protection, and a new study finds that the brain continues to generate neurons in adulthood.

199.title: Sperm Bank Could Help Save Bees
199.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientist plan to create a sperm bank to help boost numbers of deteriorating bee populations, crazy ants continue to invade the U.S.'s Southeast costing millions in damage, and a new study proves vegetable can be part of a heart healthy diet.

200.title: Dirty Little Secrets from the Restroom About Hand Washing
200.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, new research shows that one in ten people don't wash their hands after using the restroom, dust storms are getting worse in the western U.S., and Canadian Astronaut Chris Hadfield announces his retirement.

201.title: Protecting Astronauts from Radiation During Space Travel
201.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists look to plastic as a better shielding solution for cosmic radiation, the Andromeda galaxy is full of black holes, and monstrous mosquitoes invade Florida.

202.title: Gene Patenting Not Allowed
202.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the U.S. Supreme Court rejects Myriad Genetic Inc. gene patent request, researchers clock the speeds of cheetahs, and researchers predict the world population will reach 11 billion by the end of the century.

203.title: The MEN in Menopause
203.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, men are the reason women go through menopause, the medical community could be open to hackers, and global warming threatens LA's skiing crowd.

204.title: Meet America's New Astronauts
204.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA announces its 2013 astronaut candidates, a new search and rescue robot has some feline inspiration, and MIT creates 3D printed bone.

205.title: Yuri Gagarin's Death Solved
205.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists solve the mystery of the death of the first man in space, winds on Venus are picking up, and red meat is linked with Type-2 Diabetes.

206.title: A Billion Pixels of Mars

207.title: House Bill Threatens NASA's Budget
207.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Congress could impede the plan for a manned mission to Mars, researchers find emotions in the brain, and the possible link between gluten antibodies and autism.

208.title: A Member of the Family
208.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, dogs and their owners have a closer bond than we thought, unattractive people have a hard time at work, and bison are shedding some weight.

209.title: IRIS Prepares for Launch
209.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, dogs and their owners have a closer bond than we thought, unattractive people have a hard time at work, and bison are shedding some weight.

210.title: Habitable Planet Hunting
210.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists find new possible habitable planets, grizzly bears cause serious debate, and why women aren't entering the field of computer science.

211.title: Retiring Research Chimps
211.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NIH retires most of their research chimps, evolution has a hand in baseball, and a tiny robot is making his way to the ISS.

212.title: IRIS Launch Successful
212.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, IRIS begins its mission, Voyager 1 is nearing the edge of the solar system, and the science behind food addiction.

213.title: A Shock to the System
213.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the meteor that hit Russia sent shock waves around the globe, robots are competing in soccer, and why impulsivity is a good thing.

214.title: Batteries Be Gone
214.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a high school student invents a battery-free flashlight, there's a new IMAX movie coming to town, and how space weather is affecting our technology.

215.title: Naming Pluto's Moons
215.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the IAU makes its official naming selections for 2 of Pluto's moons, dust might be the biggest obstacle for lunar rovers, and why crocodiles are so sensitive.

216.title: Opportunity Trip Is Half Over
216.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA's Opportunity Rover is halfway to Solander Point on Mars, the UN warns of the hottest decade in recorded history and military sonar is disrupting the behavior of blue whales.

217.title: Solar Impulse Crosses U.S.
217.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Solar Impulse completes its trek across the US, SpaceX's Grasshopper rocket reaches new heights, and studying the surface of asteroids.

218.title: Bedtimes and Brainpower
218.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, regular bedtimes for kids help their cognitive development, earthworms help track Earth's climate history, and we're seeing the future of IVF.

219.title: New Rover Planned for 2020
219.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA is looking ahead to 2020, the next national park could be on the moon, and how choirs put their whole heart into their music.

220.title: It's a Touchscreen World
220.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, any surface can become a touch screen, IBEX is tailing the solar system, and wildfires are on the rise.

221.title: Meteor Crater Found in Iowa
221.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a giant impact crater is discovered beneath a town in Iowa, Earth's rotation has slowed down, and how elephants cool down in the heat.

222.title: Soothing Sad Songs
222.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, why sad songs don't make you sad, your employer is looking at your Facebook, and antibiotic overuse is a worldwide problem.

223.title: Zero-gravity Coffee Cup
223.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, NASA deals with liquid behavior in space, Hubble uncovers Neptune's 14th moon, and listening to a volcano before it erupts.

224.title: T. Rex Attack Preserved
224.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a single fossilized tooth proves the T. Rex was a predator, a new dino discovered in Utah, and sugar is linked to cancer.

225.title: Astronomers Strike Gold
225.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, neutron star collisions forge gold, watching a black hole eat gas, and new ways to power batteries.

226.title: Feeling the Burn
226.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, your personality could predict your taste for spicy foods, a deeper look into how insects move, and what Curiosity is uncovering about the Martian atmosphere.

227.title: U.S. Drops the Bomb
227.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, US drops unarmed bombs on the Great Barrier Reef, F-1 engines found in the Atlantic are from the Apollo 11 mission, and hackers are going after your SIM card.

228.title: SOHO's Hot New Shots
228.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, SOHO reveals some of our sun's secrets, Cassini looks at Earth from Saturn, and dolphins name each other with whistles.

229.title: Two-Faced Oxytocin
229.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the love hormone will also cause you pain, the fossil of a dino's full tail found in Mexico, and the UK readies to open a mystery coffin.

230.title: Forming Martian Valleys
230.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, how valleys formed on the Martian surface, the Hobbit Humaniod looked like us, and using magnetics to interact with your phone.

231.title: Getting Wise About Comets
231.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, rocks orbiting between Jupiter and Neptune are determined to be comets, the full moon affects sleep, and height is linked with cancer.

232.title: 365 Days of Discover
232.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Curiosity completes one year on Mars, the man who cloned Dolly is looking at mammoths, and camping could help you sleep.

233.title: 100% Cultured Beef
233.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists show off their lab grown meat, fruit is grown to taste like candy, and an endangered horse gets help from science.

234.title: Perseid Meteor Shower
234.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Perseid meteor shower approaches, the sun's magnetic field is about to flip, and Mars One moves forward with plans to colonize Mars.

235.title: Doggie Empathy
235.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, dogs mimic your yawns, NASA is looking to a future landing on Jupiter's moon Europa, and hot cocoa may improve your thinking skills.

236.title: 100% Effective Malaria Vaccine
236.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists have high hopes for a new malaria vaccine, Hubble solves the mystery of the Magellanic Stream, and figuring out if fish feel pain.

237.title: Finding Mona Lisa
237.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, uncovering the real Mona Lisa, how your final resting place could be space, and the common ingredient that fights lung cancer.

238.title: Elon Musk Plans for Hyperloop
238.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a new form of transportation could speed up cross country travel, what happens in the brain when you die, and using famous faces to diagnose dementia.

239.title: RHex the Parkour Robot
239.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a U of Penn robot takes lessons from parkour, crowdsourcing could improve weather reporting, and your eyes are the key to determining your risk of having a stroke.

240.title: An Astronaut's Gotta Eat
240.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, researchers look for the best way to feed astronauts on an extended mission to Mars, SpaceX's Grasshopper rocket completes the next stage of testing, and a new inhaler could replace insulin shots.

241.title: Location of Voyager 1 Disputed
241.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the location of the Voyager 1 spacecraft is being debated, NASA is looking for a way to save the Kepler space telescope, and a new mammal is identified by the Smithsonian.

242.title: Social Media Scammers
242.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, a virus is capable of boosting your likes and followers, exercise may take months before it helps you to sleep better, and studying debris from February's meteor strike.

243.title: Coffee Linked to Liver Health
243.plot: Coffee and tea reduce fatty liver, scientists may soon be able to read your thoughts, and a new exoplanet is found.

244.title: Voyager 2 at the Edge
244.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, Voyager 2 nears interstellar space, Google's bringing Internet to far off places, and scientists create lightning in the lab.

245.title: Recreating the Auroras
245.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, scientists create the auroras in a lab, NASA creates a collage of Earthlings, and sleep can help you learn.

246.title: Getting Back to Business

247.title: Spitzer's 10 Years of Success
247.plot: On this episode of the Daily Orbit, the Spitzer telescope celebrates 10 years in space, the oldest globe showing the New World is discovered, and energy now comes in a spray.

42.title: Allergic to Bees? It's Protection!
42.plot: On this episode of On Science, allergies to bee stings were evolutionarily important, NASA's assembling their telescope A-team, and lions in Uganda are dying off.

-1.title: Water for Allen Planets
-1.plot: On this episode of On Science, the Comet of the Century fizzles out, scientists discover a new organ in male koalas, and energy drinks are bad for your heart.

imdb.title: On Science
plot: A fun and engaging look at what's hot in science and technology today. Get up to speed in short order on the latest in Science, Space, Technology and Health.::Anonymous
